title.narrative: Nigeria Smart Grid Reverse Trade Mission, through Futron Corporation

description.narrative: The Initiative supports U.S. private sector participation in the implementation of smart grid transmission and distribution projects in Nigeria. The Initiative, which includes a Reverse Trade Mission and a Workshop, seeks to expose U.S. suppliers of technologies and services to market, project development, and procurement opportunities in Nigeria. The initiative also seeks to expose Nigerian decision makers to U.S. electricity distribution technologies and services, as well as policies, regulations, and financing mechanisms that can support the implementation of smart grid projects in Nigeria.

description.narrative: This initiative supports U.S. private sector participation in the implementation of smart grid transmission and distribution projects in Nigeria. The initiative, which includes a Reverse Trade Mission (RTM) and a Workshop, seeks to expose United States (U.S.) suppliers of technologies and services to market, project development, and procurement opportunities in Nigeria. The initiative also seeks to expose Nigerian decision makers to U.S. electricity distribution technologies and services, as well as policies, regulations, and financing mechanisms that can support the implementation of smart grid projects in Nigeria.

title.narrative: Bonny Island Branching Unit & Cable Landing Station, through HIP Consult, Inc.

description.narrative: A USTDA grant to Backbone Connectivity Network (Nigeria) Limited, a privately-owned company in Nigeria, funds a feasibility study ("Study") for the development of a subsea internet cable branching unit and cable landing station on Bonny Island, along with terrestrial network infrastructure deployment and a Tier 3 data center ("Project"). The Study will analyze the technical and commercial viability of the Project, along with a situation analysis, the development of an infrastructure map and a market demand analysis. Successful implementation of the Project will provide much-needed redundancy of telecommunications infrastructure in the South-South region of Nigeria.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - ipNX FTTX Network Analysis, through Nationwide CLEC LLC

description.narrative: This USTDA grant funds a feasibility study (Study) for the Nigerian internet service provider, ipNX Nigeria Limited to develop an expanded fiber to the premises (FTTX) network in Lagos and other urban areas in Nigeria. This Study is expected to provide the necessary technical, economic, regulatory, and financial analysis needed to deploy an expanded FTTX network that will provide last mile connectivity to residential and commercial clusters in Lagos, Nigeria and beyond. The U.S. firm Nationwide CLEC LLC, d/b/a CCG Consulting, is carrying out the Study on a sole-source basis.

title.narrative: Darway Coast Energy Access Project, through CJ Aron Associates, Inc.

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study for Darway Coast Nig., a privately-owned company in Nigeria, to develop approximately 95 mini-grids, including approximately 80 isolated mini-grids for communities and 15 distributed generation units for commercial, industrial, and institutional (CI&I) customers, primarily in southern Nigeria (Project). The CI&I entities could include markets, hospitals, and other key social and economic entities that support resiliency. When implemented, the Project is expected to provide reliable and resilient energy access for an estimated 60,000 people living in communities not connected to the grid and/or being served by CI&I entities.

description.narrative: This $455,000 feasibility study is investigating the technical, financial, and feedstock requirements for a proposed $80 million, 100 megawatt natural gas-fired captive power plant that is being developed by Honeywell Group for its food processing, cold storage, and agro-allied industries at the Flower Gate industrial park in Ogun State, Nigeria. The USTDA assistance is promoting the application of innovative U.S. technologies and contributing to the U.S. government's Power Africa initiative, which seeks to double access to electricity for African residential and industrial consumers.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Gas Based Industrial Complex, through Government of Nigeria

description.narrative: This $257,000 pre-feasibility study is evaluating various types of petrochemical facilities that could produce fertilizer chemicals such as urea and ammonia, as well as the potential development of a petrochemical complex that could produce ethylene, propylene, and benzene products. The study is analyzing the domestic and international markets, defining prospective locations, proposing feedstock options, and addressing any potential barriers for the products that could be produced as a result of the project. In addition, the study is providing the Honeywell Group with tools and training to support its strategy for a gas-based industrial complex. Honeywell Group has agreed to share costs to complete the study.

The DS contractor developed detailed Terms of Reference and a budget estimate for the study, as well as confirmed U.S. industry competitiveness and foreign competition for the project.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Hospital Modernization Study, through Government of Nigeria

description.narrative: This grant supports a feasibility study to assist Nigeria's Federal Ministry of Health to assess the modernization of ten existing and three new hospitals in twelve states across Nigeria through a Public-Private Partnership framework. The study will help the Nigerian government meet their healthcare reform goals by better enabling improvements in the country's hospitals to be financed and implemented. The project costs are being shared by the sole-source contractor, General Electric Company (Fairfield, CT).

description.narrative: This grant of $467,300 provides funding for technical assistance for the privatization of Nigeria's two largest power plants, the 600 MW Shiroro Hydro-power Plant located some 75 miles to the north-west of Abuja, and the 1,320 MW gas-fueled Egbin Power Plant near Lagos. This involves a technical and financial analysis to prepare the plants for privatization. The contractor also provides hands-on training on the development of a computer model capable of doing discounted cash flow analyses, internal rate of return calculations, revenue requirements, and tariff calculations worked up in joint BPE sessions and explained in formal seminars.
